Hi Jim,

Glad you found my stuff of interest. A dam fine contribution by yourself
causing much enlightenment.

I wrote:
>>Now the screw has been known for thousands of years, but all previous
>>examples were carved from other softer materials like wood. The early
>>iron and later steel screw had to be pains takingly built up around a
>>core with a "V" sectioned piece of wire or bar. I know a guy who has
>>done it, and it isn't easy at all. But once you know how.... BOOM!

You replied:
>This sounds confusing to me. Is it not one piece?

Er sorry about the confusion, but nope, and
> Or was it cast? 

Nope again. 

As I understand it these early screws were made in two pieces, firstly a
separate spiral of V sectioned wire, which was in turn wrapped around
the cylinder of in this case the breach plug, and soldered/welded in to
position to form a screw; sorry, don't know how, neither an engineer nor
a metallurgist. But this was done so that the V shaped wire would engage
to the inside face of the tube. Whether or not the tube was pre cut, or
if the screw was self tapping, not being intended for removal I don't
know.

Sorry that I can't be of anymore help than that.

Yours

Dean

(Dean Wayland)
